translation: Good afternoon, everyone.
transcript: 大家下午好。

translation: I’m Chen Qiufan.
transcript: 我是陈楸帆。

translation: Our topic today may sound futuristic.
transcript: 今天我带来的这个话题，可能听起来有点呃天马行空。

translation: It’s about the “significance of science fiction novels"
transcript: 我要讨论的是“科幻小说有什么用”。

translation: Actually, this topic is rooted in a very realistic context.
transcript: 但这个话题，其实有非常现实的一个语境。

translation: About two months ago, Pan Shiyi, a well-known billionaire met his idol Liu Cixin, who I guess is also the idol of many present here today, including myself.
transcript: 大概是两个月之前，我们非常熟悉的亿万富翁，呃潘石屹潘潘总，他见到了他的偶像，我相信也是在座非常多人，包括我在内的一个偶像，刘慈欣老师。

translation: He met Mr. Liu to take photos of him and also ask him a few questions.
transcript: 那么他其实见刘老师是为了给他拍照，同时呃问他一些问题。

translation: As we know, with the Three Body Problem becoming a sensation, many Internet practitioners and investors have borrowed various useful concepts from the novel.
transcript: 大家知道，随着《三体》的爆火，其实非常多的互联网从业者，包括投资人等等，都从《三体》里面读解出非常多有用的概念。

translation: Such as dimension reduction attack, the Dark Forest Theory and the Three Body management.
transcript: 比如说降维攻击，比如说黑暗森林法则，比如说三体管理学等等这样一些概念。

translation: Some entrepreneurs have gone so far as to invite Mr. Liu to be their counsellor.
transcript: 甚至很多这样的一些老总，他会请大刘去当顾问。

translation: Hoping to draw on his “magic power” to dispel the mist in reality and catch a glimpse of the future.
transcript: 希望借助他的这种“神力”，拨开现实迷雾的一角，窥见未来。

translation: Like Mr. Liu introduced, he attended this year’s World Blockchain Conference held in Wuzhen.
transcript: 包括刘慈欣老师自己说过，今年他去参加了乌镇的区块链大会。

translation: Many tycoons present at the conference said that they could perceive blockchain thinking in the Three Body Problem.
transcript: 在这大会上，非常多的区块链大佬说，我从《三体》里面，读到了区块链思想。

translation: But Mr. Liu denied, “I completed that novel around 2006.
transcript: 刘慈欣老师就说，我写《三体》那会儿大概还在2006年之前。

translation: When the idea of blockchain was no where to be seen.”
transcript: 那会儿区块链思想还不知道在哪儿呢。

translation: That’s the fact. Then Pan Shiyi asked Liu Cixin many more questions concerning how science fiction novels could influence the real world.
transcript: 所以就是这样的一个环境，然后潘石屹老师，其实问了非常多，呃刘慈欣老师关于科幻小说，如何影响现实世界的一些问题。

translation: Mr. Liu is a very down-to-earth man.
transcript: 刘慈欣老师也非常的实在。

translation: He said, “I’m just a science fiction writer.
transcript: 他说，我就是个写科幻小说的。

translation: To me, science fiction is created for its own sake and anything beyond this scope is not real science fiction.”
transcript: 所有另有所指的，都不是科幻，科幻的目的就在于科幻本身。

translation: As we see, there are two very different views in this regard.
transcript: 所以大家可以看到，这两种看法是非常的不同啊。

translation: Some, like those entrepreneurs, regard a sciene-fiction writer as a Rinpoche who is capable of fortune-telling.
transcript: 有一派就是把科幻作家当成仁波切，把科幻小说当成科学算命。

translation: Others, like Mr. Liu, consider writing science fiction novels a hobby.
transcript: 但是另外派像刘老师，他就觉得，我写科幻只是一种呃业余爱好。

translation: Then what are the right attitudes respectively for science fiction readers and writers towards science fiction?
transcript: 那么作为一个科幻读者和作者，我们应该怎么样来摆正自己的心态。

translation: What on earth is the significance of science fiction?
transcript: 科幻到底有没有用呢？

translation: This is precisely the topic that I want to share with you guys here on the stage of  “Zaojiu”.
transcript: 这就是今天我来到“造就”的舞台，非常想跟大家探讨的一个话题。

translation: There is a Chinese saying that goes “The usefulness of the useless is in fact of great importance.”
transcript: 中国有一句古话，叫做无用之用，方为大用。

translation: This saying perfectly concludes the significance of science fiction novels in my view.
transcript: 我觉得这句话特别好地概括了在我心目中，科幻小说的一个作用。

translation: It is one of the most important literary genres today.
transcript: 那就是它是当今最重要的一个文类。

translation: This is not my word.
transcript: 这句话不是我说的。

translation: Actually, it was said by a former guest of Zaojiu—Yuval Noah Harari at an interview with the Wired.
transcript: 而是这个也曾经到过咱们造就舞台的赫尤瓦尔•赫拉利先生说的，他在接受连线杂志的一个采访时说了这番话。

translation: According to him, science fiction helps shape new ideas such as AI and bio-technology in the mind of the general public.
transcript: 他说，科幻小说帮助大众形塑了对于比如人工智能、生物科技等等新事物的这种理解。

translation: Those technologies will subvert our life and society within decades.
transcript: 那么这些技术，会在接下来的几十年内，彻底地改变我们的生活以及社会。

translation: Let’s look back to the birth of science fiction in 1818.
transcript: 那么回到科幻小说诞生的之初，1818年。

translation: That was an age of change characterized by industrial revolution, mass production, subsequent layoff and.
transcript: 那是一个变革的时代，工业革命、机器大生产，让许多的产业工人下岗。

translation: Of course, breakthroughs in biology and electromagnetics.
transcript: 同时，生物学、电磁学也取得了突破。

translation: Back then, the Black Death plagued the European Continent.
transcript: 这时候欧洲大陆，其实肆孽着黑死病。

translation: A group of young British who loved arts and literature fled to Geneva.
transcript: 一群来自英国的文艺青年跑到了日内瓦去避难。

translation: There they got bored and came up with the idea of telling a ghost story each day to kill time.
transcript: 很无聊啊，他们就提出了，我们每天来讲一个鬼故事。

translation: Among them was an 18-year-old girl named Mary Shelly.
transcript: 其中有一位，当时只有年仅18岁的少女，叫玛丽•雪莱。

translation: She told a story about a scientist who combined the knowledge of biology, anatomy and electrodynamics to create a new creature that had never existed on earth before.
transcript: 她讲了一个这样的故事，就是一个科学家，利用生物解剖学以及电力学的知识，制造出一个世界上从来没有过的生命。

translation: That creature, in return, destroyed its creator.
transcript: 那么这个造物，反过来又摧毁了它的创造者。

translation: This story was later written into a novel called Frankenstein.
transcript: 就是这样的一个故事，它叫《Frankenstein》。

translation: Which must be familiar to you all.
transcript: 我相信大家都非常了解。

translation: The story is universally accepted as the origin of modern science fiction.
transcript: 这个故事就被称为，现代科幻小说的一个缘起。

translation: It actually set a high standard for science fiction novels, as it targeted gene-editing and ethical issues that still trouble people today.
transcript: 这个起点非常的高，因为它探讨的这些问题，其实到现在，包括不久前大家知道的关于基因编辑、伦理的问题，其实跟这个故事也是一脉相承。

translation: Do we have the right to create a new creature via technology?
transcript: 我们是否有权利，利用科技，去创造一个新的生命？

translation: What will be the relationship between that creature and man?
transcript: 这个创造物，跟我们人类之间的关系又是什么？

translation: That’s what science fiction is about.
transcript: 其实科幻小说，面向的就是这样。

translation: As technology keeps advancing, human civilization as a whole is faced with anxieties concerning cognition, emotion, ethics and institution.
transcript: 我们随着科技的不断地发展，人类作为文明一个整体，它面对的许多认知上、情感上、伦理上、制度上的这种焦虑。

translation: How does science fiction deal with such anxieties?
transcript: 那么科幻小说，怎么样来处理这些焦虑呢？

translation: Those anxieties originate from information asymmetry and our incomprehension and rejection of new things.
transcript: 这种焦虑来源于，一方面，信息的不对称，我们对新事物的不理解、不接受。

translation: According to Arthur Clarke, man tends to overestimate a technology’s short-term impact but underestimate its long-term influence.
transcript: 就像克拉克所说的，人类总是在高估一项技术，所带来的短期的冲击，但是低估它长期所带来的影响。

translation: Today, we will discuss science fiction as a literary genre and try to discover how it is different from romantic and Wuxia novels, or realistic fiction.
transcript: 所以今天其实我要探讨的就是科幻小说，作为一种文类，它为什么跟言情、武侠，或者现实主义不一样？

translation: What enables science fiction to process the anxieties concerning human civilization?
transcript: 它有什么样的特质，能够来处理人类文明的这种焦虑？

translation: I turn to seek help from three theorists in history.
transcript: 我从历史上找到了三个理论家。

translation: Some of their theories may help us understand how science fiction can achieve so.
transcript: 他们的一些理论，可以帮助我们来理解科幻小说它到底是如何发挥这种功用的。

translation: This first one is Darko Suvin, who is a Croatian born Canadian jew.
transcript: 那么第一个叫达科•苏文，他其实是出生于前南斯拉夫的一个加拿大裔的犹太人。

translation: In fact, he has a tough leftist background. Based on Russian formalism and from a poetic and aesthetic perspective.
transcript: 所以他其实有非常强的左派的背景，他从苏联的形式主义的立场，从诗学和美学的观念出发。

translation: He for the first time ever in history established a systematic science fiction theory.
transcript: 第一次在历史上建立了一套针对呃科幻小说的系统性的理论。

translation: Why does it matter so much?
transcript: 为什么说这个这么重要？

translation: Because prior to that, all critics had reviewed science fiction novels from a perspective of mainstream literature, or rather traditional pure literature.
transcript: 因为在此之前，所有的评论家其实都是用主流文学，传统的这种纯文学的视角来评判科幻小说。

translation: For example, in China, science fiction novels are widely considered readings for children.
transcript: 比如像在中国，很多人会说，科幻小说就是给小孩儿看的。

translation: Some Chinese readers hold that the Three Body Problem does not have much “literariness”.
transcript: 《三体》文学性不强。

translation: With its characterization, particularly female characterization, being two-dimensional and dull.
transcript: 人物特别平板、苍白，尤其是里面的女性人物塑造。

translation: Darko Suvin’s theory, however, provides a brand-new coordinate system to distinguish science fiction from other literary genres.
transcript: 但达科•苏文其实提出了这套理论，从一个崭新的坐标系，去告诉我们，科幻小说究竟为何区别于其他的文学样式。

translation: He introduced a concept called “cognitive estrangement”.
transcript: 他提出的这样一个概念，叫做“认知陌生化”。

translation: Which remains very influential till this day.
transcript: 这个概念其实直到现在都有非常大的影响。

translation: What does that concept mean?
transcript: 这个概念是什么意思呢？

translation: Let’s look at his coordinate system to figure it out.
transcript: 让我们来看这样的一个坐标系。

translation: The vertical axis represents the degrees of cognition.
transcript: 纵轴代表着认知性的高低。

translation: While the horizontal axis represents the stages of aesthetic and poetical transition from naturalism to estrangement.
transcript: 横轴代表着审美，以及诗学上的这种从自然主义到陌生化的不同的阶段。

translation: Let me give you an example.
transcript: 那么我来举一个例子。

translation: There’s a saying that “You reap what you sow”.
transcript: 比如说，种芝麻得芝麻，种西瓜得西瓜。

translation: This is very much in line with our understanding of the objective world and nature.
transcript: 这是非常符合我们对于客观世界、自然界的一种认知。

translation: It is logically self-consistent and allows us to perceive and understand it rationally.
transcript: 它是逻辑自洽的，它有非常强的这种呃能用理性去认知和理解这种概念。

translation: So we can put “You reap what you sow” on the top left, namely, the genre of Chinese local literature.
transcript: 那么种芝麻得芝麻，种西瓜得西瓜，那我们可以把它放在左上角，它是一个现实主义的乡土文学。

translation: What if “You sow sesames and get melons”?
transcript: 那如果种芝麻得西瓜。

translation: This is in fact beyond our conventional cognition.
transcript: 这其实超越了我们对日常的这种认知。

translation: It is a phenomenon that is against our logic.
transcript: 它是一个不符合我们逻辑思维的一个现象。

translation: So let’s just place it on the bottom right.
transcript: 那么我们把它放在右下角。

translation: It may fall into the genre of myth, folklore, fantasy, or magic realism.
transcript: 它可能是神话，可能是民间传说，可能是奇幻或者魔幻现实主义。

translation: If I sow a sesame, transform it via bio-gene technology and get a melon-sized sesame.
transcript: 那么如果我们种下了一颗芝麻，通过生物基因的改造技术，让它长成了像西瓜这么大的一个芝麻。

translation: That would fall into the category of science fiction literature on the top right.
transcript: 那么它就是科幻文学，它就放在右上角。

translation: This is in fact what is described in Xiao Lingtong's Travels in the Future.
transcript: 其实这就是《小灵通漫游未来》里，所描述的。

translation: According to the story, one could get melon-sized sesames by sowing sesames.
transcript: 种芝麻得芝麻呃西瓜那么大的芝麻。

translation: That’s the concept of science fiction.
transcript: 就是这么一个概念。

translation: So now we know science fiction novels should be placed on top right of that coordinate system.
transcript: 让我们知道了，科幻小说，其实是放在这么一个坐标系的右上角。

translation: As we see, cognition and estrangement are not a contradictory pair.
transcript: 我们可以看到认知性和陌生化，它其实不是一对撕裂的概念。

translation: Rather, they complement each other and are combined into an organic dialectical unity.
transcript: 它其实是相辅相成，中间有着非常呃有机的、辩证统一互动的这种关系。

translation: Such a relationship turns science fiction reading into an intellectual experiment and adventure, which keeps challenging, breaking and reshaping our cognitive and aesthetic limits.
transcript: 正是这种关系，使得我们阅读科幻小说成为了一种不断挑战、打破并且重塑我们认知与审美边界的一种思想的实验与冒险。

translation: The second theorist is a Korean American scholar named Seo-Young Chu. She graduated from Harvard and is now a teacher in New York.
transcript: 那么我要介绍一下第二位理论家，她其实是一位韩裔美籍呃学者，她毕业于哈佛，叫朱瑞瑛，现在在纽约教书。

translation: In 2010, she published a book called Do Metaphors Dream of Literal Sleep?.
transcript: 她在2020年出版了一本书，叫做《隐喻梦见了文字的睡眠吗》。

translation: You can tell this book rhymes with the title of Philip K. Dick’s classic novel Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?.
transcript: 其实这个名字，你就可以看出，她其实是向菲利普•迪克的《仿生人梦见了电子羊》这本经典的著作。

translation: That book was later adapted into movie Blade Runner.
transcript: 最后被改编成了《银翼杀手》。

translation: In the book, Chu puts forward a radical view, that is, science fiction is a high-intensity realism.
transcript: 所以她在里面提出了非常激进的一个观点，就是科幻是一种高密度的现实主义。

translation: While traditional realism is merely a low-intensity and low-energy science fiction.
transcript: 而我们传统所认为的现实主义，只是一种低密度的、低能量的科幻。

translation: How can such an argument be valid?
transcript: 这个论点怎么成立呢？

translation: She directs us to ancient Greece in the Aristotle era, when all artistic and literary creations were imitations and representations of reality.
transcript: 她把我们的视线，引向了古希腊，在亚里斯多德的时代，文艺包括所有的文学创作，其实是对于现实的一种模仿和再现。

translation: In the industrial era, particularly in recent years.
transcript: 但到工业化时代之后，尤其到现在越来越多的高新科技。

translation: However, with high-techs keeping upgrading, the real picture of the world has been highly complicated and abstracted, transcending the limits of our daily experience.
transcript: 日新月异，其实整个世界的现实图景，以及高度的复杂化，以及抽象化，它远离了我们日常经验的限度。

translation: Traditional literary discourse can no longer effectively help imitate or represent the reality.
transcript: 传统的这种文学话语，已经无法再有效地帮我们去模仿以及再现现实。

translation: Under such circumstances, metaphor emerges.
transcript: 所以这时候隐喻出现了。

translation: There are some rhetorics that must be familiar to you all.
transcript: 大家肯定非常熟悉这样的一些说法。

translation: For example, the earth is a village; the Internet is an information super-highway.
transcript: 比如说地球是一座村落，互联网是一条信息高速公路。

translation: These are all metaphors used to explain abstract concepts.
transcript: 这其实都是运用了一种隐喻的手法来解释一个非常抽象的概念。

translation: There are numerous concepts alike, including globalization, cyberspace and the most-talked-about community with a shared future for mankind.
transcript: 这样的概念非常多，包括全球化、网络空间，包括我们最熟悉的人类命运共同体。

translation: What’s the most interesting thing in science fiction novels?
transcript: 所以在科幻小说里，最有趣的一点是什么？

translation: For a rhetoric metaphor, the ontology and the metaphorical object refer to the same thing.
transcript: 我们把这个比喻的本体和喻体，其实它是一回事儿。

translation: Again, take today’s repeatedly mentioned Ready Player One as an example.
transcript: 举一个今天被反复Cue到的一个例子，就是《玩儿家一号》。

translation: In Ready Player One, cyberspace is projected as an “oasis”—a virtual world in which the protagonist can shuttle back and forth for adventure.
transcript: 在《玩家儿一号》里其实大家都可以看到，网络空间被塑造成一个主角可以在里面自由穿梭，去进行冒险的一个虚拟的世界：绿洲。

translation: The “oasis” in fact features a realistic function.
transcript: 那么这个绿洲其实它具备了现实的一个功能。

translation: That is, playing a very important part in narration while serving as a metaphor of cyberspace.
transcript: 就是它在叙事上，扮演着非常重要的角色，同时，它在文本上又是一个对网络空间的一个比喻。

translation: Let’s look at this picture.
transcript: 那我们再来看这幅图。

translation: This pig is almost as big as a little elephant.
transcript: 这只像小象一样大的一个猪。

translation: Next to it is a poem entitled “Fat Pig Competes with Elephant”.
transcript: 它旁边有一句诗，叫做“肥猪赛大象”。

translation: This picture is a satire and metaphor of the agricultural fashion of boasting and exaggeration during the Great Leap Forward era.
transcript: 其实这个放到大跃进时期，它其实是对农业浮夸风的一个讽刺，一个隐喻。

translation: However, this picture can also be understood as a depiction of Elephant without Nose, a classic 1958 science fiction by Chi Shuchang.
transcript: 但是如果把它放到1958年，迟叔昌老师的一部经典的科幻小说叫做《割掉鼻子的大象》里。

translation: In the novel, a pig, via gene modification, grows as big as an elephant.
transcript: 那么它就是把猪通过基因技术改造成可以长成大象那么大的一个size。

translation: Readers of that science fiction can perceive and understand that pig from perspectives of science-based realism and reality-based metaphorical language.
transcript: 所以在这个科幻小说里，我们可以把这一只猪，从科学的真实性和现实的隐喻性两个角度去同时进行理解和认知。

translation: That shows how technology today keeps refreshing our cognition.
transcript: 这就是为什么我们说在当今、在当下，科技的概念不断冲刷我们的认知。

translation: science fiction is a literary genre capable of depicting and representing complicated scenarios in reality with higher intensity and energy in a more comprehensive and panoramic perspective.
transcript: 而科幻小说是一种，能从更大的密度、更强的能量，而且更全面、全息的这种角度去描摹、去再现我们复杂的现实场景的一种文学样式。

translation: So it is the biggest realism.
transcript: 它是最大的现实主义。

translation: The third theorist may be even more familiar to you.
transcript: 那么我们再来看第三个，可能大家会更为熟悉一点的一个学者。

translation: He is a well-known Western theorist of marxism and post modernism.
transcript: 他也是非常著名的西方马克思主义以及后现代理论的一位大家。

translation: His name is Fredric Jameson.
transcript: 他叫弗雷德里克•呃詹姆逊。

translation: In 2005, he published a very influential work entitled Archaeologies of the Future.
transcript: 他在2005年有一本非常重要的著作，叫做《未来考古学》。

translation: In this book, he considers science fiction to be an ideological framework which examines today from a future perspective and sees oneself from others’ perspective.
transcript: 在这本书里，他把科幻小说当成一种从未来看当下，从他者看自我的思想框架。

translation: Such an ideological framework enables us to form our critical “cognitive mapping” of the reality.
transcript: 通过这种思想框架，我们可以对现实进行批判性的认知测绘，为什么这么说呢？

translation: For him, science fiction is like a utopian-style literary genre.
transcript: 他其实从一个乌托邦的角度，来看待科幻小说。

translation: In nature, longing for utopia is an irreducible instinct and essence of human existence.
transcript: 他认为科幻，乌托邦其实是一种呃人类的无法化约的心理本能，它是一种存在的本质。

translation: Just like Freud’s sexual drive, it is an essence of human existence.
transcript: 就像弗洛伊德的性冲动一样，它是一种本质性的存在。

translation: In this sense, science fiction is not about prediction or escape, but an experiment of imagination.
transcript: 所以，它在这里科幻小说不是预测、不是逃避，而是一种想象力的实验。

translation: It is a mechanism inspiring perfectionism.
transcript: 是一种对完美的启发机制。

translation: So it is just a theory of knowledge, rather than “existence” in ontology.
transcript: 所以它是一个认识论，而不是本体论上的存在。

translation: In the 20th Century, classic utopian literature, which was derived from Utopia, a masterpiece written by Thomas More in 1526, lost its previous orthodoxy.
transcript: 但是到了20世纪之后，基于托马斯•摩尔的1526年写的《乌托邦》这个经典文本，所延展出来的这种经典乌托邦文学，已经失去了在历史上的正统位置。

translation: How come?
transcript: 为什么呢？

translation: The 20th Century witnessed two world wars, nuclear explosion and the Cold War.
transcript: 20世纪，我们经历了两次世界大战，经历了核子呃战争，经历了冷战。

translation: After the Cold War, capitalism and consumerism worked like protons, blocking people’s diversified utopian-style imaginations of the future from the mainstream discourse.
transcript: 而在冷战之后，资本主义、消费主义的生活形态，已经像质子一样封锁了在主流话语里面对于未来的这种乌托邦图景的多样性的想象。

translation: But Jameson soon discovered that outside the mainstream discourse system there’s a science fiction world.
transcript: 但这时候詹姆逊发现，在主流话语之外，就是科幻小说的这个领域。

translation: Which was marginalized and was a relatively closed circle.
transcript: 因为它一直被边缘化，它是一个相对封闭的一个圈子。

translation: Inside this circle, utopia was used as a critical discourse to form dystopian fiction, a literary genre familiar to us.
transcript: 在这里面乌托邦被剁作为一种批判性的话语，也就是我们熟悉的反乌托邦小说。

translation: It maintained an imagination and exploration of the future.
transcript: 继续保持着对未来的这种想象和探索。

translation: In fact, Jameson has done a lot of research in utopian fictions of different periods.
transcript: 他其实研究了非常多的呃这个各个时期的一些乌托邦小说。

translation: And he discovered that in the USA in the 1960s-1970s.
transcript: 包括他发现在美国六七十年代。

translation: A group of writers, particularly science fiction writers were keen on topics such as gender and ethnicity.
transcript: 有一群作家，科幻作家，特别喜欢写作性别与种族的这种话题。

translation: Why?
transcript: 为什么呢？

translation: Because patriarchy and technology were the two major elements that dominated then mainstream discourse of capitalist society and maintained hegemony.
transcript: 因为这两者，男权、技术，是当时占据着资本主义社会主流话语权、主要霸权的两大元素。

translation: It’s worth mentioning that during that period.
transcript: 其中有非常重要的一部作品。

translation: LeGuin one of my favorite anthropologists and also a well-known science fiction & fantasy writer, created a fiction entitled The Left Hand of Darkness.
transcript: 就是来自于我非常喜欢的一位人类学家，也是非常呃经典的科幻奇幻作家，勒奎恩，她写作了一部小说叫《黑暗的左手》。

translation: The book is set on a frigid planet called Gethen, or Winter, which is at dozens degrees below zero Celsius all the year round.
transcript: 她设想了一个，常年在零下几十度的一个冬星。

translation: Technology of this planet is advanced yet it is a feudal society.
transcript: 这颗冬星，科技非常发达，但它同时是一个封建制的社会。

translation: Unlike people on earth, people on that planet are a race of androgynous  humans who maintain an inter-sexual or androgynous state for two thirds of a month.
transcript: 这上面所有的人跟地球人不一样，不是生下来就有男女两种性别，在每个月三分之二的时间里，他都是处于一种中性，或者说雌雄同体的这种状态。

translation: During estrus periods, when one meets another, there may be physiological, psychological or behavioral changes in both of them.
transcript: 而只有当一个人进入了发情期，然后遇到了另一个，同样处于发情期的个体，这时候，两个人的生理、心理或者行为，它会开始发生变化。

translation: One may change to a male and the other to a female to allow intercourse.
transcript: 其中一个人变成雄性，一个人变成雌性，然后他们可能会开始交配。

translation: It is noteworthy that such a sexual change is random.
transcript: 但是大家要注意一点，这两个人的变化是随机的。

translation: In other words, at different times any individual may be either a man or a woman.
transcript: 有可能一个人这次变成男的，下次就变成女的。

translation: Once “she” gets pregnant, she will keep being female until childbirth.
transcript: 如果她怀孕了，她就会一直保持这种雌性的状态，直到她分娩完毕。

translation: After that, she will return to an inter-sexual state.
transcript: 然后再变回中性。

translation: That’s the world LeGuin imagined.
transcript: 所以就是这样的一个社会里，她设想了这样的一种设置。

translation: The whole story centers on such an outlook or world view.
transcript: 然后所有的故事都是围绕这样一个设置，世界观去展开。

translation: In the view of people on Gethen, the male-female binary gender system on earth is definitely sexual perversion.
transcript: 在冬星人看来，地球人这种二元对立的这种性别，完全就是一种性变态。

translation: Why did Jameson speak so highly of the utopian imagination in this work?
transcript: 所以詹姆逊为什么这么高度的评价这部作品对乌托邦的一种想象？

translation: There are two reasons.
transcript: 就是因为。

translation: First, it negates gender politics by blurring gender boundary.
transcript: 一它通过取消性别的方式否定了性别政治。

translation: Second, it depicts a high-tech feudal society to negate the historical determinism-based view.
transcript: 第二，它通过描述了一个封建制的高科技社会来否定在我们非常主流的话语权里。

translation: Which forcibly relates capitalism with technological development in the mainstream discourse.
transcript: 把社会把资本主义跟科技发展做强联系的这种历史决定论的观点。

translation: That’s how Jameson views science fiction.
transcript: 所以这就是詹姆逊对科幻小说的看法。

translation: He considers it an indirect strategy for us to understand our true self and seize the moment.
transcript: 他觉得这是一种我们去理解自我，把握当下的一种间接的策略。

translation: Thus, such utopian and dystopian worlds were shaped.
transcript: 我们通过塑造这下，这样一些乌托邦、反乌托邦的世界。

translation: Writers have shaped a variety of “others’ worlds”, such as space opera, cyberpunk and post-human era.
transcript: 我们去塑造很多的这种，包括太空歌剧，包括赛博朋克，后人类时代等等这样一些他者世界。

translation: They negate the reality by institutional means and make readers more aware of their “state of imprisonment” both spiritually and ideologically while reading such stories.
transcript: 我们对现实进行一种制度性的否定，我们让读者在阅读这样一些故事的过程中，更加清楚地看清我们自己精神上、意识形态上，一种被囚禁的状态。

translation: In this way, they retain an enclave for literary imagination in a real society.
transcript: 就这样，我们保留了在真实社会里面的一块文学想象性的一个飞地。

translation: Thanks to this enclave, science fiction writing and criticism is not just textual production.
transcript: 这个飞地，我们的写作、我们的批评不再只是一种文本的生产。

translation: But also real intervention in social and political issues.
transcript: 而是对了社会、对政治有了一种现实性的介入和干预。

translation: Science fiction writers advance the utopian process of human nature and history in their novels.
transcript: 就是这样，我们把人性和历史的乌托邦进程，在科幻小说里继续往前推进。

translation: That’s my brief introduction of the three theorists and their views.
transcript: 介绍了三前面三位大师的一些理论之后。

translation: As we see, although their focuses vary.
transcript: 大家可以看到，尽管他们互有侧重。

translation: They have invariably explored four relationships, namely, the relationship science fiction have with literature, technology, reality and future.
transcript: 但是无非都是对科幻与文学，科幻与科技，科幻与现实，科幻与未来，这四组关系进行了思考。

translation: With the four relationships in mind, when reviewing Frankenstein, the Three Body Problem and even Xiao Lingtong's Travels in the Future.
transcript: 那么当我们了解了这四组关系之后，再回过头去看《Frankenstein》 再去看《三体》，甚至《小灵通漫游未来》。

translation: We will have a refreshed feeling.
transcript: 我们会有全新的感受。

translation: Anyway, theories are constantly renewing.
transcript: 当然，说了这么多，理论之树常青。

translation: Or rather, theories may be grey and dull, but the “tree of life” is forever green and vigorous.
transcript: 呃理论是灰色的，但人生之树常青。

translation: Why do writers create science fiction?
transcript: 我们为什么要写作科幻？

translation: Take myself as an example.
transcript: 我必须回到最初。

translation: Looking back, when I was 13, I read 2001: A Space Odyssey by Arthur Clarke, who’s also Liu Cixin’s favorite writer.
transcript: 我13岁时，看了阿瑟•克拉克，也就是刘慈欣老师最喜欢的那位作家，他的《2001太空漫游》之后。

translation: And I looked up at the sky, marveling at the vast universe and feeling the triviality of myself.
transcript: 我仰望星空，觉得宇宙如此的浩瀚，而我自己是特别的渺小。

translation: It is such an original affection and awe that drove me to pick up the pen to create a science fiction world of my own.
transcript: 就是这种原初的感动和敬畏，让我开始拿起笔来写作，创作我自己的一个科幻世界。

translation: Many people wonder if science fiction can eliminate my real-life anxieties or not.
transcript: 就是会有非常多的人会回到我们这个话题，那么科幻到底能不能解决我的现实的焦虑？

translation: My answer is definitely NO.
transcript: 我的回答当然是不能。

translation: For example, in my early science fiction career.
transcript: 比如说在最早我写作科幻的时候。

translation: I could barely make any money out of it.
transcript: 其实它无法给我任何经济上的回报。

translation: Besides, I have to constantly struggle with deadline pressure, which is quite annoying.
transcript: 比如说它可能会在截稿日期前，会给我不断的这种压力，就这是让我嗷嗷焦虑的一件事儿。

translation: From another perspective, science fiction writing allows me to experience a diversity of worlds, resonate with many great souls in history.
transcript: 但是写作科幻，让我经历了无数的不同的世界，让我在历史中跟许多伟大的心灵去共振。

translation: And make friends with science fiction fans from around the world.
transcript: 也包括让我结识了非常多世界各地热爱科幻，呃喜欢科幻的这些朋友。

translation: It’s said that science fiction can eliminate the structural anxiety of human civilization as a whole.
transcript: 那么我们说科幻能够解决的是人类文明整体的这种结构性的焦虑。

translation: What is structural anxiety?
transcript: 什么叫结构性的焦虑？

translation: In recent years, I have been frequently asked, “Will AI rob us of our jobs?
transcript: 就是近几年有很多人问我，AI会不会让人下岗？

translation: Will machine replace and even enslave humans?”
transcript: 机器会不会取代人类甚至奴役人类？

translation: This is what I call the structural anxiety of human civilization as a whole.
transcript: 这种就是我所谓的文明的整体性的焦虑。

translation: To me, the answer is very simple.
transcript: 那么对于我来说，我的答案也非常的简单。

translation: It is better to embrace change than to worry about the unknown.
transcript: 与其焦虑未知，不如拥抱变化。

translation: Human species is no different from other species in the sense that they are all faced with the issues of birth, aging, illness and death.
transcript: 人类作为一个物种，它跟其他的物种其实是一样的，它有它的生老病死。

translation: Eventually, mankind will go extinct.
transcript: 它最终也会迎接灭亡的一天。

translation: Let’s assume that we can pass part of our human civilization onto the civilization of another species.
transcript: 但倘若，我们能把人类的这些文明的一部分传承到下一个文明，另一个物种。

translation: For example, we can keep many diversified architectures and art forms on earth.
transcript: 比如说，我们在地球上保留下，许多多元性的建筑或者艺术。

translation: We can also send human information to the universe via signals.
transcript: 比如说，我们向太空发射人类的这种信息。

translation: It’s like the golden record attached to Voyager 2.
transcript: 像最近旅行者2号，它携带的那个金色的唱片。

translation: Or one day we may enable machine or other species to understand all about man, including our creations and feelings.
transcript: 比如说我们教会机器，以及其他的物种理解人类，包括人类的创造以及情感。

translation: I bring a new copy of mine here today.
transcript: 我带来了一本新书。

translation: It’s entitled Algorithms for Life.
transcript: 它叫《人生算法》。

translation: In fact, I contributed six stories to this book.
transcript: 在这书里我其实写了六个故事。

translation: All of them are about man-machine relationships.
transcript: 全部是关于人与机器的这种关系。

translation: Actually, at my invitation, Wang Yonggang also contributed to this book.
transcript: 其实我邀请了我以前的同事。

translation: Wang is my former colleague at Google and current CTO of Sinovation Ventures.
transcript: 呃google的前同事，现在是创新工场CTO，王咏刚老师。

translation: He wrote a story about an AI robot which, by imitating my writing style, becomes Chen Qiufan 2.0.
transcript: 他写作了一个AI机器人，这个AI机器人，通过学习我的写作风格，它变成了陈楸帆2.0。

translation: I Just need to input a keyword, my 2.0 version would present a number of literary works in my style.
transcript: 我只要输入一个关键词，它就可以给给我吐出一堆，貌似我写的那种风格的文学作品。

translation: So I pieced Chen Qiufan 2.0’s writing with 1.0’s (i.e. my writing) together to form a new story.
transcript: 所以我把机器写的东西，跟我陈楸帆1.0，你可以这么叫我，放在一块儿，形成了一个新的故事。

translation: It’s my work of joint authorship with AI about interactions between man and AI.
transcript: 用我跟AI一起来写作一个关于人类和AI的故事。

translation: The funny thing is, I thought I completed a story with the help of AI robot.
transcript: 但最后我发现非常有意思的一点就是，我以为是我用机器帮我完成了一个故事。

translation: But it turned out that I was used by AI to complete a literary work of its own.
transcript: 但最后发现其实是机器利用我来写作了一个文学作品。

translation: That’s it.
transcript: 所以这就是。

translation: We all live in an age of noises and roars, whether we are fans of 2D culture, idol culture, computer games, Korean drama or movies.
transcript: 我觉得在我们这个喧嚣与骚动的时代，不管你热爱的是二次元，热爱是粉丝，热爱的是游戏、韩剧还是电影。

translation: The best way to deal with anxiety is to maintain an open and optimistic attitude to embrace the unknown, the future and the reality.
transcript: 我们面对焦虑最好的方式，就是保持一种开放乐观的心态，去拥抱未知，去拥抱明天，去拥抱现实的。

translation: Thank you all!
transcript: 谢谢大家！
